questions.text: Gatekeeper of the heart is :
Brain blood supply
All are vasodilators except :
Ventricular filling is followed by:
Prepotential phase in the SA node is due to all except :
The blood pressure regulatory system that is also known as a buffer system is :
Mean arterial pressure is :

options.label: A
options.text: Artithmetic mean of systolic and diastolic pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Longarithmic mean of systolic and diastolic pressure

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • D. 60% diastolic + 40% systolic: The mean arterial pressure (MAP) is a weighted average of the systolic and diastolic pressures. Since the heart spends more time in diastole than systole during the cardiac cycle, the MAP is closer to the diastolic pressure. Typically, the MAP is calculated using the formula:
  • • MAP = Diastolic pressure + 0.33 × (Systolicpressure - Diastolic pressure)
  • • In simplified terms, this means that the MAP is closer to 60% of the diastolic pressure and 40% of the systolic pressure.
  • • Incorrect responses:
  • • A. Arithmetic mean of systolic and diastolic pressure: This is incorrect because the arithmetic mean of systolic and diastolic pressures would simply average the two values. However, the heart spends more time in diastole, so the MAP is not an equal average of the systolic and diastolic pressures.
  • • B. Logarithmic mean of systolic and diastolic pressure: This is also incorrect. The logarithmic mean is not used to calculate MAP. The MAP calculation is based on a weighted average rather than any logarithmic transformation of the pressures.
  • • C. 40% diastolic + 60% systolic: This is incorrect because the distribution of the weights in the MAP formula is the reverse. The MAP is closer to 60% diastolic and 40% systolic, not the other way around.
